displayed_text: Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.”

Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day. Patient: Uh sometimes none a day. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Oh OxyContin, once a day. Yes, you know I was taking the ten milligrams maybe twice a day and then once a day. And if it’s acting up a little bit in the morning well then the OxyContin, I’ll take that. But it’s not every day. As far as staying ahead of the pain then stop the pain. Doctor: You said you move your bowels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And uh how’s your appetite?

Patient: Well, besides that, huh, that pain I’m still getting. Except for now I’m getting a pain right here. I’m thinking this is from this. I’m not sure. But, huh- Doctor: So where’s the pain at that you had before? Patient: Down in here. Doctor: In your buttock? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or it’s hips and buttock? Patient: Hip. Doctor: Okay. Huh, okay, and, huh, any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And how’s your headaches been? Patient: One side of pain right here, I don’t have any. Doctor: And no trouble swallowing?

Patient: That reminds me of another question. Doctor: Um hmm. Come in. Healthcare Professional: Guess who? Doctor: Hey does he get a copy or is it just us for the…? Healthcare Professional: No, not usually but we can. Doctor: Okay, no then we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Do you want a copy? Doctor: He doesn’t need more paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Okay I need it. Doctor: Sorry, you had one more question? Patient: Shingles? Doctor: Yes. Patient: I have had a doctor tell me no, I’ve had a doctor tell me yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Not only did it not work, but pause]] Mm, hmm? Patient: So, then we’ll go up front and get the appointment. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we leave. Doctor: So about well six weeks would be about June eighteen, so sometime that week I need a PSA. Family Member: Okay. Patient: June eighteen for the blood work? Doctor: Yes, from C____ sometime that week. Patient: Yeah right. pause]] Family Member: Now are his bloodwork test results available online? Doctor: No. We don’t have it an outpatient patient portal yet.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So my hope is that with time the fatigue will get better. Patient: Is that a good thing because the testosterone feeds cancer, right? Doctor: Well, it’s a good thing and a bad thing. It’s a double-edged sword. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But you and I made the decision when we first met after a discussion with Dr.__ as well – Dr. – Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this stuff only goes to bone and your hernia surgery is not bone so it’s all workable. Patient: Okay they may say it’s not necessary either. Doctor: Yeah, correct, correct, but go ahead and have your primary refer you to a hernia surgeon. Okay? Patient: Okay, yep. Doctor: Might as well get that all taken care of. Patient: Okay, alright. Well, this sounds good to me.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But we, the is if you drop out Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but every once in a while we make an exception , but in general the cavet is dropping out early is you Patient: And this therapy is part of the trial, it’s not just something that’s being done, it’s associated with this trial. It’s not and say this is what I want to do at this time. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: This only comes with this trial. Doctor: That is generally true. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um now the last time, there are some radiologist oncologists that insurance is Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And again, Dr. T has done that on a handful of patients,

Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him. Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it?

Family Member: And then you eat breakfast. Patient: And then I’ll get up again and check it again. Doctor: Alright. Yeah. I think you could get off the carbs. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It would be better. That’s all. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta.

Patient: I’m still having problems. Doctor: It takes a year generally and your surgery was when August? Patient: Uhh September. Doctor: September and so do you have any flows at all? Patient: Uh no you know it acting like it wanna but never… Doctor: And you’re taking the medicine? Patient: Uh those pills they didn’t do anything. Doctor: Okay well don’t stop taking ‘em because… Patient: Well I took ‘em. Doctor: Oh you so you finished taking them and you ran out of them is what you mean? Patient: Yeah, yeah I took ‘em. Doctor: You should have some refills. Did you look at the bottle?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Venlafaxine or Effexor for mood – thirty-seven and a half. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know. What’s another name for it? Doctor: Venlafaxine or Effexor. Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, I do, yeah. Doctor: And the Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Xtandi? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And the Zofran, you take it as needed. Anything else that I need to add to this list, that we don’t have on this list? Patient: No. No. Doctor: Nothing for moving your bowels, slow your bowels down? Family Member: Oh you don’t do that

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process?
